title: Essex lorry deaths: How people-smugglers hide human cargo from thermal cameras
text:

Security officials have revealed how people smugglers hide their human cargo from thermal cameras at busy ports following the deaths of 39 Chinese migrants.

Two days after a container filled with 39 dead bodies was found in an industrial estate in Grays, Essex, work to unravel what happened continues.

What has been established is that the container containing the 39 dead people arrived at Purfleet port, Essex, on the River Thames.

It had travelled from Zeebrugge in Belgium.

While security staff at the UK port have been warned away from speaking to the press - with their jobs at risk if they do so - two have spoken under the condition of anonymity.

(Image: PA)

(Image: Press Association)

The border force worker explained how refrigerated lorries are used to get around thermal imaging cameras designed to detect the warmth of bodies.

"Thermal imaging equipment doesn't work on refrigerated containers. They are simply too cold, and you can't pick up any heat that might be coming from somebody hidden inside," they told The Mail Online.

"The smuggling gang must have known this, it just goes to show how clever they are. They are constantly looking for loopholes and sadly, it's ended up with all these people losing their lives."

Another security worker said the people inside the lorry "never stood a chance".

(Image: Humphrey Nemar)

(Image: Press Association)

Even if the refrigerator had been turned off, they claimed, the airtight nature of the container would have suffocated anyone inside after a period of time.

Both members of staff said Purfleet did not have the resources to check every lorry that came through the port.

Refrigerated units are rarely opened for fear the goods inside would be spoiled, they said.

Each year 200,000 containers and the same amount of trailers and cars come through the port.

It is feared the 39 people who lost their lives decided to take on the incredibly risky journey with help from the Snakeheads, notorious people-smugglers with links to ­ruthless Triad gangsters in China.

(Image: PA)

They are said to tout the streets for victims, enticing them with the promise of a better life before charging thousands of pounds to take treacherous trips to the West in a “fly-drive” service costing £30,000.

They are usually flown from the Fujian region of China to Europe, all expenses paid, then placed in accommodation. They are then placed in goods lorries and driven in darkness, without food, ventilation, water or toilet facilities.

A source who cannot be named claimed migrants who make it to the West start paying back the Snakeheads the moment they get a job, over three years.

If they cannot pay, the gangs will put pressure on their families back in China to hand over the cash.

(Image: Sky News)

Yesterday police began moving the bodies of the migrants from the lorry to a mortuary.

Officers are trying to find out if driver Mo Robinson, from ­Portadown, Co Armagh, knew the 39 were in the trailer being pulled by his Scania truck.

His parents, Mark, 50, and Nichola, are believed to have flown from Northern Ireland to support their son in England. Officers searched their modern semi-detached home in the nearby village of Laurelvale.

They also raided a £300,000 home in nearby Markethill, where it is believed the suspect lives with his pregnant girlfriend. A third property in the area was also searched.
description: Security guards at Purfleet in Essex have spoken of how people smugglers avoid detection and slip through the border
